items.title: I can calculate work done using W = Fs cos θ
items.what: Work is the energy transferred when a force causes displacement. The formula accounts for the angle between force and displacement direction.
items.why: This allows you to determine energy transfer in real situations where forces may not act directly along the direction of motion, such as pulling a cart with a rope at an angle.
items.example: A person pulls a golf cart 324 m with a force of 250 N at 60° to the horizontal. Work done = 250 × 324 × cos(60°) = 40,500 J

subtopic.name: Work and Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the concept of work done by forces, calculating work from force-displacement graphs, and understanding kinetic and gravitational potential energy. You will learn to apply formulas and analyse energy transformations quantitatively.
subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can explain why forces perpendicular to displacement do no work
items.what: When a force acts perpendicular to the direction of motion, no energy is transferred to the object. The component of force parallel to displacement is zero.
items.why: This explains why objects in uniform circular motion maintain constant kinetic energy even though a centripetal force acts on them continuously.
items.example: A satellite orbiting Earth experiences gravitational force perpendicular to its velocity, so its kinetic energy remains constant at 3.0 × 10^10 J throughout the orbit

subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can calculate work from the area under a force-displacement graph
items.what: The area under a force-displacement graph represents the total work done. For constant force this is a rectangle, for varying force it may be a triangle or trapezium.
items.why: This graphical method allows you to find work done even when force varies with distance, which is common in real situations like braking or spring compression.
items.example: A force decreases linearly from 950 N to 0 N over 300 m. Work = 0.5 × 950 × 300 = 142,500 J

subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can apply the law of conservation of energy to closed systems
items.what: In a closed system, energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another. The total energy remains constant.
items.why: This principle allows you to track energy through transformations and solve problems where measuring forces directly would be difficult.
items.example: A 1500 kg car pushed 12.6 m with 900 N does 11,340 J of work, but if friction is 900 N, all energy becomes thermal energy and kinetic energy remains zero

subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can calculate gravitational potential energy using Eg = mgΔh
items.what: Gravitational potential energy is the energy stored due to an object's position in a gravitational field. It depends on mass, gravitational field strength and height change.
items.why: This allows you to determine energy available for conversion to kinetic energy when objects fall, or energy required to lift objects to a certain height.
items.example: An 80 kg builder climbs a 4.6 m ladder. Change in gravitational potential energy = 80 × 9.8 × 4.6 = 3606 J

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the concept of work done by forces, calculating work from force-displacement graphs, and understanding kinetic and gravitational potential energy. You will learn to apply formulas and analyse energy transformations quantitatively.
subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can calculate kinetic energy using Ek = ½mv²
items.what: Kinetic energy is the energy due to motion. It is proportional to mass and the square of velocity, meaning doubling speed quadruples kinetic energy.
items.why: Understanding kinetic energy explains why stopping distances increase dramatically with speed and helps analyse collisions and energy transformations.
items.example: A 465 kg motorbike travelling at 117 km/h (32.5 m/s) has kinetic energy = 0.5 × 465 × 32.5² = 245,156 J

subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can calculate change in kinetic energy using ΔEk = ½mvf² - ½mvi²
items.what: Change in kinetic energy is found by subtracting initial kinetic energy from final kinetic energy. A negative value indicates energy lost from the object.
items.why: This calculation shows how much energy an object gains or loses during acceleration or deceleration, essential for analysing braking and collision scenarios.
items.example: A 93.2 kg cyclist slowing from 63 km/h to 54 km/h loses kinetic energy: 0.5 × 93.2 × (17.5² - 15²) = 3790 J lost to friction and heat

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the concept of work done by forces, calculating work from force-displacement graphs, and understanding kinetic and gravitational potential energy. You will learn to apply formulas and analyse energy transformations quantitatively.
subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can analyse energy transformations using Ek(initial) + Eg(initial) = Ek(final) + Eg(final)
items.what: When gravitational potential and kinetic energy transform into each other, their sum remains constant in a closed system. Energy converts between forms without loss.
items.why: This equation allows you to find speeds at different heights or maximum heights reached without knowing the forces acting during motion.
items.example: A swimmer stepping off a 10 m platform with zero initial velocity reaches the water at v = √(2 × 9.8 × 10) = 14 m/s

subtopic.why: Understanding work and energy is fundamental to explaining how forces transfer energy between objects and systems. These concepts apply to everyday situations from lifting objects to analysing vehicle motion and determining speeds at different heights.

items.title: I can calculate momentum using p = mv
items.what: Momentum is the product of an object's mass and velocity. It is a vector quantity with both magnitude and direction.
items.why: Momentum quantifies motion and is conserved in collisions, making it essential for analysing interactions between objects from subatomic particles to vehicles.
items.example: A 2450 kg car travelling at 81 km/h (22.5 m/s) north has momentum = 2450 × 22.5 = 55,125 kg m/s north

subtopic.name: Momentum and Impulse
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can apply conservation of momentum to solve collision problems
items.what: In an isolated system with no external forces, total momentum before collision equals total momentum after collision: m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂.
items.why: This principle allows you to predict velocities after collisions without knowing the details of forces during impact, applicable to sports, vehicle crashes and particle physics.
items.example: Mark (86 kg at 4.35 m/s north) collides with Max (62 kg at 5.55 m/s south). After collision, Mark moves at 3.64 m/s south, so Max moves at 5.53 m/s north

subtopic.name: Momentum and Impulse
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can determine whether a collision is elastic or inelastic by comparing kinetic energies
items.what: In elastic collisions, total kinetic energy is conserved. In inelastic collisions, some kinetic energy converts to heat, sound and deformation. Compare total kinetic energy before and after collision.
items.why: Understanding energy loss in collisions explains why vehicles crumple in crashes and helps design safer collision scenarios that dissipate energy.
items.example: Two 0.150 kg carts colliding at 4.5 m/s and rebounding at 1.25 m/s: total KE before = 3.04 J, after = 0.234 J, so collision is inelastic with 2.81 J lost

subtopic.name: Momentum and Impulse
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can calculate impulse using I = mΔv = Fav × Δt
items.what: Impulse is the change in momentum, equal to the product of average force and time interval. It is measured in N·s or kg m/s.
items.why: Impulse connects momentum change to forces and time, explaining why increasing collision time reduces force, which is the principle behind airbags and crumple zones.
items.example: A 1650 kg car slowing from 54 km/h to 9 km/h in 3.45 s has impulse = 1650 × (2.5 - 15) = -20,625 N·s, requiring average force = 5980 N

subtopic.name: Momentum and Impulse
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can calculate impulse from the area under a force-time graph
items.what: The area under a force-time graph represents impulse. For varying forces, calculate area using geometric shapes like triangles, rectangles or trapeziums.
items.why: This graphical method allows you to find impulse when force varies during collision, which is typical in real impacts like car crashes or ball strikes.
items.example: A force starting at 4000 N and decreasing linearly to 3000 N over 30 minutes (1800 s) gives impulse = 0.5 × (4000 + 3000) × 1800 = 6,300,000 N·s

subtopic.name: Momentum and Impulse
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can distinguish between momentum and inertia
items.what: Momentum is mass times velocity (zero when stationary). Inertia is resistance to change in motion, depending only on mass. A stationary object has inertia but no momentum.
items.why: This distinction clarifies that heavy stationary objects are hard to move due to inertia, while moving objects have momentum regardless of their difficulty to accelerate.
items.example: An 80 kg person at 0.175 m/s has momentum = 14 kg m/s, same as a 0.02 kg bullet at 700 m/s, but the person has 4000 times more inertia

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers calculating momentum, applying conservation of momentum in collisions, understanding impulse as change in momentum, and analysing force-time graphs. You will work with one-dimensional collision scenarios.
subtopic.why: Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle that applies to all collisions and explosions. Understanding impulse helps explain why crumple zones and airbags save lives by extending collision time and reducing forces.

items.title: I can calculate spring constant from a force-extension graph
items.what: The spring constant is the gradient of a force-extension graph, calculated as k = ΔF/Δx. It represents the stiffness of the spring in N/m.
items.why: Determining spring constant allows you to predict how much a spring will compress under load, essential for designing suspension systems and safety equipment.
items.example: A spring extending from 0 to 0.3 m under forces from 0 to 8 N has spring constant k = 8/0.3 = 26.7 N/m

subtopic.name: Springs and Hooke's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Hooke's law relating force to extension, calculating spring constants from graphs, determining elastic potential energy, and understanding force-extension relationships for ideal springs.
subtopic.why: Springs are fundamental components in vehicle suspension, measurement instruments and energy storage systems. Understanding spring behaviour allows you to design systems that absorb impacts safely or store mechanical energy efficiently.

items.title: I can apply Hooke's law using F = -kx
items.what: For ideal springs, the restoring force is proportional to displacement. The negative sign indicates force opposes the direction of extension or compression.
items.why: Hooke's law allows you to calculate forces in spring systems, predict spring behaviour under load, and understand when springs will fail if extended beyond their elastic limit.
items.example: A car suspension spring with k = 15,000 N/m compressed by a 2560 N force has compression x = 2560/15000 = 0.171 m

subtopic.name: Springs and Hooke's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Hooke's law relating force to extension, calculating spring constants from graphs, determining elastic potential energy, and understanding force-extension relationships for ideal springs.
subtopic.why: Springs are fundamental components in vehicle suspension, measurement instruments and energy storage systems. Understanding spring behaviour allows you to design systems that absorb impacts safely or store mechanical energy efficiently.

items.title: I can calculate elastic potential energy using Es = ½kx²
items.what: Elastic potential energy stored in a spring is half the product of spring constant and displacement squared. Energy increases quadratically with extension.
items.why: This calculation determines energy stored in compressed or extended springs, crucial for analysing energy transfers in oscillating systems and collision scenarios involving springs.
items.example: A spring with k = 150 N/m stretched from 10 cm to 14 cm gains elastic PE = 0.5 × 150 × (0.14² - 0.10²) = 0.72 J

subtopic.name: Springs and Hooke's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Hooke's law relating force to extension, calculating spring constants from graphs, determining elastic potential energy, and understanding force-extension relationships for ideal springs.
subtopic.why: Springs are fundamental components in vehicle suspension, measurement instruments and energy storage systems. Understanding spring behaviour allows you to design systems that absorb impacts safely or store mechanical energy efficiently.

items.title: I can determine elastic potential energy from area under a force-extension graph
items.what: The area under a force-extension graph equals work done on the spring, which becomes elastic potential energy. For linear graphs, use triangle area formula.
items.why: This graphical method provides an alternative to the formula and helps visualize why more energy is needed to extend an already-stretched spring further.
items.example: A spring with k = 800 N/m stretched to 1 m stores energy = 0.5 × 1 × 800 = 400 J, shown by the triangular area under the graph

subtopic.name: Springs and Hooke's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Hooke's law relating force to extension, calculating spring constants from graphs, determining elastic potential energy, and understanding force-extension relationships for ideal springs.
subtopic.why: Springs are fundamental components in vehicle suspension, measurement instruments and energy storage systems. Understanding spring behaviour allows you to design systems that absorb impacts safely or store mechanical energy efficiently.

items.title: I can explain why progressively more energy is needed to extend a spring further
items.what: Since force increases linearly with extension but energy depends on extension squared, each additional meter of extension requires increasingly more energy than the previous meter.
items.why: This explains why springs become harder to compress or extend the more they are deformed, and why safety margins exist for maximum spring deformation.
items.example: Extending a spring from 0 to 1 m requires 50 J, but extending from 4 to 5 m requires 450 J, nine times more energy for the same distance

subtopic.name: Springs and Hooke's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Hooke's law relating force to extension, calculating spring constants from graphs, determining elastic potential energy, and understanding force-extension relationships for ideal springs.
subtopic.why: Springs are fundamental components in vehicle suspension, measurement instruments and energy storage systems. Understanding spring behaviour allows you to design systems that absorb impacts safely or store mechanical energy efficiently.

items.title: I can analyse energy transformations in horizontal spring systems
items.what: In horizontal springs, elastic potential energy and kinetic energy transform into each other. At maximum compression/extension, all energy is elastic PE. At equilibrium, all energy is kinetic.
items.why: This understanding allows you to predict speeds and positions during oscillation, essential for designing mechanical systems that oscillate without external energy input.
items.example: A mass on a horizontal spring compressed 1 m with 400 J elastic PE reaches equilibrium with 400 J kinetic energy, then extends 1 m with 400 J elastic PE again

subtopic.name: Energy Transformations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers analysing energy transformations in horizontal and vertical spring systems, understanding equilibrium positions, and tracking changes between kinetic, gravitational potential and elastic potential energy during oscillations.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can identify the equilibrium position where net force is zero and velocity is maximum
items.what: The equilibrium position is where spring force is zero (horizontal spring) or balances gravity (vertical spring). At this point, acceleration is zero and velocity is maximum.
items.why: Identifying equilibrium allows you to find the point of maximum kinetic energy and zero acceleration, crucial for analysing oscillating systems and predicting maximum speeds.
items.example: In a vertical spring with 1.25 kg mass and k = 136.1 N/m, equilibrium occurs at extension x = mg/k = (1.25 × 9.8)/136.1 = 0.090 m

subtopic.name: Energy Transformations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers analysing energy transformations in horizontal and vertical spring systems, understanding equilibrium positions, and tracking changes between kinetic, gravitational potential and elastic potential energy during oscillations.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can apply mg = kx to find equilibrium in vertical spring systems
items.what: At equilibrium in a vertical spring, the upward spring force equals the downward gravitational force. This gives the natural rest position for a hanging mass.
items.why: This equation allows you to calculate how far a spring will stretch under a given load, essential for designing suspension systems and ensuring springs operate within safe limits.
items.example: A 5 kg mass on a spring with k = 122.5 N/m hangs at equilibrium position x = (5 × 9.8)/122.5 = 0.40 m below the unstretched position

subtopic.name: Energy Transformations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers analysing energy transformations in horizontal and vertical spring systems, understanding equilibrium positions, and tracking changes between kinetic, gravitational potential and elastic potential energy during oscillations.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can analyse energy transformations in vertical spring systems using total energy conservation
items.what: In vertical springs, gravitational PE, elastic PE and kinetic energy transform into each other. Total energy remains constant: mgΔh + ½kx² + ½mv² = constant.
items.why: This comprehensive energy equation allows you to solve complex problems involving vertical springs, such as calculating maximum compression when a mass falls onto a spring.
items.example: A 3.77 kg mass dropped from 5.2 m onto an 11.6 m spring compresses it to 5.45 m. Total gravitational PE loss = elastic PE stored: (3.77)(9.8)(5.2 + 6.15) = 0.5k(6.15)²

subtopic.name: Energy Transformations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers analysing energy transformations in horizontal and vertical spring systems, understanding equilibrium positions, and tracking changes between kinetic, gravitational potential and elastic potential energy during oscillations.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can describe acceleration changes during vertical spring oscillation
items.what: At maximum extension/compression, acceleration is maximum. At equilibrium, acceleration is zero. Acceleration always points toward equilibrium and increases with displacement from it.
items.why: Understanding acceleration patterns explains why oscillating objects slow down away from equilibrium and speed up toward it, fundamental to all oscillatory motion.
items.example: A 1.25 kg mass on a vertical spring has maximum acceleration a = 9.8 m/s² at the top and bottom of oscillation, and zero acceleration at equilibrium

subtopic.name: Energy Transformations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers analysing energy transformations in horizontal and vertical spring systems, understanding equilibrium positions, and tracking changes between kinetic, gravitational potential and elastic potential energy during oscillations.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can track energy percentages through a complete oscillation cycle
items.what: At any point during oscillation, the sum of kinetic, gravitational and elastic potential energy percentages equals 100%. Energy continuously shifts between these forms.
items.why: Tracking energy percentages provides a clear picture of energy flow through oscillating systems, helping visualize abstract energy transformations in concrete terms.
items.example: In a vertical spring at equilibrium, a system might have 50% gravitational PE, 25% elastic PE and 25% kinetic energy, totaling 100% of system energy

subtopic.why: Understanding energy transformations in oscillating systems explains phenomena from earthquake engineering to musical instruments. It allows you to predict velocities, forces and positions at any point in an oscillation cycle.

items.title: I can solve sticky collision problems where objects combine after impact
items.what: In sticky collisions, objects join together after impact and move with a common final velocity. Total momentum is conserved: m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = (m₁ + m₂)v.
items.why: Sticky collisions model many real scenarios including train coupling, tackled players in sports, and projectiles embedding in targets. These collisions are always inelastic.
items.example: A 200 g toy train at 1.22 m/s is hit by 150 g plasticine at 2.45 m/s. Combined system moves at v = (0.2 × 1.22 + 0.15 × 2.45)/0.35 = 1.75 m/s

subtopic.name: Collisions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers applying conservation principles to different collision types, analysing sticky collisions where objects combine, explosive collisions where objects separate, and comparing elastic versus inelastic collisions through energy calculations.
subtopic.why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can solve explosive collision problems where objects separate from rest
items.what: In explosive collisions, a single object breaks into separate parts. Initial momentum (often zero) equals the sum of final momenta of all parts.
items.why: Explosive collisions explain recoil when firing projectiles, rocket propulsion, and nuclear decay. Understanding them allows calculation of recoil velocities and energy distributions.
items.example: A 59 kg cyclist at 5 m/s throws a 0.5 kg ball forward at 10 m/s. Cyclist's new velocity: (59.5 × 5) = (0.5 × 10) + 59v, giving v = 4.96 m/s

subtopic.name: Collisions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers applying conservation principles to different collision types, analysing sticky collisions where objects combine, explosive collisions where objects separate, and comparing elastic versus inelastic collisions through energy calculations.
subtopic.why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can calculate energy lost in inelastic collisions
items.what: Energy lost to heat, sound and deformation equals the difference between total kinetic energy before and after collision: ΔE = Σ½mu² - Σ½mv².
items.why: Quantifying energy loss explains why crumple zones save lives by converting kinetic energy to deformation rather than injuring passengers with elastic rebounds.
items.example: Two 1.35 kg blocks colliding at 2.5 m/s and rebounding at 0.9 m/s lose energy: 2(0.5 × 1.35 × 2.5²) - 2(0.5 × 1.35 × 0.9²) = 7.29 J lost

subtopic.name: Collisions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers applying conservation principles to different collision types, analysing sticky collisions where objects combine, explosive collisions where objects separate, and comparing elastic versus inelastic collisions through energy calculations.
subtopic.why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can compare forces in collisions using impulse and force-time graphs
items.what: For the same momentum change, longer collision time means smaller average force. Force-time graphs with equal areas (impulse) but different peaks show different maximum forces.
items.why: This principle explains why airbags and padding reduce injury. Extending collision time reduces peak force, even though the momentum change remains the same.
items.example: Two crash tests with impulse 100,000 N·s: Car A peaks at 3000 kN over 50 ms, Car B peaks at 2500 kN over 60 ms. Car B has the better crumple zone

subtopic.why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can apply momentum conservation to problems with objects initially at rest
items.what: When one object is initially stationary, momentum conservation simplifies to m₁u₁ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂. The initially moving object transfers momentum to the stationary one.
items.why: Many practical collision scenarios involve stationary targets, from billiard balls to particle accelerators. This simplified equation makes calculations more manageable.
items.example: An 85.7 kg hockey player at rest hits a 154 g puck to 22.5 m/s north. Player's recoil velocity: 0 = 0.154 × 22.5 + 85.7v, giving v = 0.0404 m/s south

subtopic.why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can verify momentum conservation experimentally using before and after measurements
items.what: To verify momentum conservation, calculate total momentum before collision (Σmu) and after collision (Σmv). If equal within experimental uncertainty, momentum is conserved.
items.why: Experimental verification confirms theoretical predictions and helps identify external forces that might violate momentum conservation, such as friction or magnetic forces.
items.example: Two carts colliding: before = (4 × 5) + (2 × 2) = 24 kg m/s. After = (4 × 4) + (2 × 4) = 24 kg m/s. Momentum conserved, confirming no external horizontal forces
